shortdef: a one-sided contest : an easy or uncontested victory
a horse race with only one starter

dt: {bc}to move along on foot {bc}advance by steps
{bc}to come or go easily or readily
{bc}to go on foot for exercise or pleasure
{bc}to go to first base as a result of a base on balls
{bc}to pursue a course of action or way of life {bc}conduct oneself {bc}{sx|behave||}
{bc}to be or act in association {bc}continue in union

dt.t: the British and American peoples will … {wi}walk{/wi} together side by side … in peace

dt: {bc}to move about in space outside a spacecraft
{bc}to move in a manner that is suggestive of {a_link|walking}
{bc}to stand with an appearance suggestive of strides
{bc}to cause (an animal) to go at a walk {bc}take for a walk
{bc}to haul (something, such as an anchor) by walking round the capstan
{bc}to compel to walk (as by a command)
{bc}to bring to a specified condition by walking
{bc}to follow on foot for the purpose of measuring, surveying, or inspecting
{bc}to move (an object) in a manner suggestive of walking
{bc}to pass on foot or as if on foot through, along, over, or upon {bc}{sx|traverse||}, {sx|perambulate||}
{bc}to perform or accomplish by going on foot
{bc}to give a base on balls to
{bc}to perform (a dance) at a walking pace
{bc}to give up or leave behind willingly {bc}{sx|abandon||}
{bc}to survive (an accident) with little or no injury
{bc}to outrun or get the better of without difficulty
{bc}to take over unexpectedly from someone else {bc}{sx|steal||1d}
{bc}to win or gain especially by outdoing one's competitors without difficulty
{bc}to walk under compulsion over the side of a ship into the sea
{bc}to resign an office or position under compulsion
{bc}to go through (a theatrical role, a familiar activity, etc.) perfunctorily (as in an early stage of rehearsal)
{bc}to guide (someone, such as a novice) through an unfamiliar or complex procedure step-by-step
{bc}to deal with or carry out perfunctorily

et: Middle English {it}walken{/it} "to roll, toss about (of the sea, waves), wander, journey, go, go on foot, stroll, move about on earth (of a dead person's spirit), be in motion, circulate, be present, live," going back to Old English {it}wealcan{/it} (strong verb) and {it}wealcian{/it} (weak verb) "to toss about, work with the hands, turn over (in the mind), (of waves or the sea) to roll, surge," going back to Germanic {it}*walkan-{/it} (whence also Middle Dutch {it}walken{/it} "to knead, full [cloth]," Old High German {it}giwalchen{/it} "fulled, thickened," as weak verbs Old Icelandic {it}válka{/it} "to roll, stamp," {it}velkja{/it} "to toss about"), of uncertain origin

The Middle English verb experienced a remarkable degree of semantic diversification not paralleled in other Germanic languages, taking it far from its Old English sources, and leading to the usual modern meaning "to go by foot"; see detailed discussion of forms and meanings in {it}Oxford English Dictionary,{/it} third edition. — The Germanic verb {it}*walkan-{/it} has been compared with Sanskrit {it}válgati{/it} "(s/he) leaps, bounds, (it) surges," and, more remotely, Latvian {it}val͂gs{/it} "rope." However, as pointed out by G. Kroonen ({it}Etymological Dictionary of Proto-Germanic,{/it} Brill, 2013), there is a parallel verb {it}*walgōn-{/it} evident in Middle Dutch {it}walghen{/it} (in {it}mi walghet{/it} "I feel nauseous"), Middle Low German {it}walgen{/it} "to wrestle, strive," Old High German {it}walgōn{/it} "to roll." If this etymon goes back to Indo-European {it}*u̯olg{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} it cannot be related to the Sanskrit verb. Both {it}*walkan-{/it} and {it}*walgōn-{/it} have been seen as representing root extensions of Indo-European {it}*u̯el-{/it} "roll"; see {et_link|welter:1|welter:1}.
shortdef: to move along on foot : advance by steps
to come or go easily or readily
